summary: This document is a series of email exchanges between defense attorney Bruce Barket and federal prosecutors regarding poor conditions and alleged intimidation faced by their client, Nicholas Tartaglione, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). The emails discuss scheduling a call to address these issues. This document contains email correspondence from August-November 2019 regarding conditions at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) and the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death. It includes complaints from a defense attorney about client treatment, scheduling of a call to discuss MCC conditions, and internal BOP communications about the ongoing Epstein suicide investigation. This document contains email correspondence from 2019 involving attorneys from the law firm Barket Epstein Kearon Aldea & LoTurco, LLP (and later Epstein Sacks PLLC) discussing legal matters related to a client, Nick Tartaglione, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). It includes scheduling, visitation requests, and administrative procedures for a private investigator. A forwarded Washington Post article on political/legal issues is also included. This document is a news briefing covering multiple topics, with a significant focus on the political fallout from the Jeffrey Epstein case. It details calls for Labor Secretary Alex Acosta's resignation over his role in Epstein's 2008 plea deal, President Trump's defense of Acosta, and Attorney General William Barr's recusal decisions. It also explores Trump's past relationship with Epstein and his pattern of distancing himself from controversial associates. This document is a forwarded email newsletter from The Washington Post titled 'The Daily 202', dated July 10, 2019. It contains a collection of news summaries covering various topics including Saudi Arabia's lobbying efforts in the US, a Saudi princess's trial, tech industry news, and political commentary. The document appears to be part of a larger collection of Epstein-related materials, though this specific chunk contains no direct references to Jeffrey Epstein or his case. This document is an email chain from August 30, 2019, discussing the allocation of Temporary Duty (TDY) costs for staff at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. The discussion centers on whether these costs, related to implementing new procedures and policies following an incident (implicitly the Jeffrey Epstein incident), should be covered by a special project fund, similar to how costs for an earlier incident at MDC Brooklyn were handled. The Bureau of Prisons (BOP) officials indicate that while some expenses for an 'after action team' were covered, general TDY costs due to staff shortages were not initially approved due to budget constraints and priority spending directives from the Department of Justice. This document contains internal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) emails and a Google Alert digest from August-September 2019. It discusses logistical and financial issues related to staff travel (TDY) to MCC New York following Jeffrey Epstein's death, a Google Alert summary of news about the BOP, and a brief email chain about attorney access to Epstein. It also references a 'SW Chronological Log' concerning a logbook error for Epstein's suicide watch. This document contains internal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) emails and logs regarding the suicide watch of Jeffrey Epstein on July 23-24, 2019, and subsequent discussions about funding for Temporary Duty (TDY) staff costs related to the incident at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It reveals administrative confusion over logs and significant expenses incurred. This document contains a series of emails from August to December 2019 concerning staffing and inmate management at MCC facilities, with specific focus on Jeffrey Epstein and another inmate, Michael Elansky. It reveals internal BOP communications about Epstein's removal from psychological observation and suicide watch prior to his death, and concerns about another inmate's medical neglect. This document contains email correspondence and a detailed timeline related to Jeffrey Epstein's death in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York on August 10, 2019. It includes a minute-by-minute suicide timeline, notifications to officials, and emails between prison staff, attorneys, and investigators regarding the incident and prison conditions. This document contains email correspondence and attachments related to legal visits and conditions at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It includes a complaint from attorney Bruce Barket about poor conditions for his client and a separate email chain regarding obtaining visitation approval for a private investigator to visit a different inmate. The document reveals procedural details for legal visits and investigator access at the federal detention facility. This document contains email chains from July and November 2019. The July emails discuss an urgent issue where Jeffrey Epstein's attorney, Martin Weinberg, was denied access to meet with him at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) after his arrest. The November emails are a forward regarding a meeting with a new warden and mention the Epstein suicide investigation. This document contains email correspondence from November 2019 between a federal judge and a Bureau of Prisons attorney regarding a new warden and an upcoming meeting. It also includes forwarded Google Alerts about the Bureau of Prisons from July 2019 and January 2020, which mention Jeffrey Epstein's suicide attempt and investigation. This document is a collection of email correspondence and attachments from within the U.S. Bureau of Prisons (BOP) concerning Jeffrey Epstein's detention, suicide attempt, and death. It includes internal communications about attorney access, media inquiries, and a detailed timeline of the events surrounding Epstein's suicide on August 10, 2019. This document contains email correspondence from the Bureau of Prisons system regarding inmate Jeffrey Epstein's medical care and administrative matters while incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. It includes discussions about his CPAP machine, medication, and an extension cord memo, as well as a Google Alert about his death. This document contains email correspondence and attachments from the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York regarding Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and death. It includes a memo about an extension cord for his CPAP machine, emails about releasing his medical/mental health records post-mortem, and a detailed suicide timeline of the events surrounding his death on August 10, 2019. This document is a collection of email correspondence and attachments from August 2019, primarily concerning the death of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) and subsequent investigations. It includes a letter from the MCC Warden to Judge Berman confirming investigations into the July 23 incident, a media inquiry about MCC conditions, a detailed timeline of Epstein's death on August 10, 2019, and a Google Alert email about prison news following Epstein's death. This document is a Google Alerts email digest from November 25, 2019, containing news headlines on prison-related topics, including a mention of Jeffrey Epstein's death in the context of prison reform. It also contains a forwarded email of 'The Daily 202' newsletter from The Washington Post dated August 14, 2019, discussing economic uncertainty, trade wars, and political news. This document is a compilation of news articles from August 2019, covering various political and international stories. A significant portion focuses on the aftermath of Jeffrey Epstein's death in federal custody, including the reassignment of prison staff, investigations into the circumstances, and the resulting political and legal fallout, including scrutiny of Prince Andrew and legal battles involving Alan Dershowitz and David Boies. This document is a forwarded email newsletter from The Washington Post's 'The Daily 202' dated August 14, 2019. It contains a collection of news summaries on various topics including ICE raids in Mississippi, migrant housing in Washington D.C., gun control debates, and media controversies. The document appears to be part of a larger collection of emails from Jeffrey Epstein's estate, but its direct connection to the Epstein case is not evident from this text. This document contains two parts: 1) A forwarded email chain from July 19, 2019, between a Supervisory Staff Attorney at the CLC and defense attorney Bruce Barket regarding inmate Nicholas Tartaglione's conditions in the SHU at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, including complaints about leaks, rodents, lighting, and denial of privileges. 2) A much longer, unrelated email newsletter from The Washington Post dated August 14, 2019, covering various political and economic news, with a significant section discussing the death of Jeffrey Epstein, the subsequent investigation, and related figures. This document contains email correspondence from July 2019 regarding access and conditions for inmate Nicholas Tartaglione, followed by an official timeline of events surrounding the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein on August 10, 2019. The emails detail defense attorney complaints about visitation delays and poor conditions at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The attached timeline provides a minute-by-minute account of Epstein's final day and the response to his death. This document contains a detailed timeline of events surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's death on August 10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, followed by a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) memorandum providing feedback on the institution's psychological reconstruction response. It highlights procedural failures, lack of documentation, and institutional bias. This document contains email correspondence and Google Alert summaries related to the Bureau of Prisons in the aftermath of Jeffrey Epstein's death. It includes internal BOP emails discussing funding for Temporary Duty (TDY) staff at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York following the incident, as well as news alerts about the BOP shake-up and public commentary on Epstein's suicide. This document contains email correspondence from the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) system, primarily discussing logistical and financial issues related to the detention and death of Jeffrey Epstein. It includes internal emails about TDY (temporary duty) costs for staff at MCC New York following Epstein's death, an out-of-office notification, an email chain about attorney access to Epstein, a Google Alert about the Bureau of Prisons, and a separate email regarding a site visit request for another inmate. The emails reveal internal BOP budgeting concerns and operational challenges in the aftermath of Epstein's death. This document is a collection of email chains from late 2019 concerning the conditions of confinement and legal representation of inmate Nicholas Tartaglione at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The emails involve discussions between Tartaglione's defense attorney, federal prosecutors, and MCC staff regarding visitation issues, cell conditions, discovery delivery, and a suicide attempt. The emails also reference a check for any investigation into Tartaglione related to Jeffrey Epstein. This document contains email correspondence primarily concerning the detention conditions and legal access issues of inmate Nicholas Tartaglione at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It includes complaints from his defense attorney about inhumane conditions, delays in legal visits, and lost property, with responses from prison staff and a federal prosecutor. A separate, brief email chain forwards an order related to the case of Jeffrey Epstein. This document contains a court order scheduling a hearing regarding the dismissal of charges against Jeffrey Epstein following his death, and includes email chains from July 2019 discussing attorney access issues for Epstein and another inmate (Nicholas Tartaglione) at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). This document is an email chain from July 2019 between defense attorney Bruce Barket and a Supervisory Staff Attorney at the New York Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), discussing the harsh conditions and access issues faced by inmate Nicholas Tartaglione. It details problems with legal visits, missing discovery materials, poor cell conditions, and disciplinary actions following a cell phone seizure. This document contains several email exchanges from Bureau of Prisons (BOP) accounts, primarily from 2019. It includes internal communications about inmate Jeffrey Epstein's suicide watch status, a forwarded news article about Attorney General William Barr, a Google Alert about the Bureau of Prisons, and a message distributing an updated timeline document for Epstein. The emails show internal BOP coordination and awareness of media coverage related to Epstein and the BOP. This document contains a detailed timeline of events leading to Jeffrey Epstein's death in custody on August 10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It includes internal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) memos reviewing the psychological reconstruction of the suicide, highlighting institutional failures, and email correspondence regarding OIG interviews and the official closure of his criminal case. This document is a forwarded email chain from July 2019 concerning inmate Nicholas Tartaglione's conditions and legal access at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It includes complaints from his defense attorney about poor conditions, lack of access to legal materials, and systemic delays in attorney visits, with responses from MCC supervisory staff and a federal prosecutor. This document is a chain of emails from July 2019 concerning inmate Nicholas Tartaglione's conditions and legal access at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It includes complaints from his attorney Bruce Barket about poor conditions, visitation delays, and missing legal materials, and responses from MCC staff and a federal prosecutor. The document also contains metadata for a separate, later email regarding a psychological observation of Jeffrey Epstein. This document is an email from an Associate Warden at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, forwarding a PDF attachment titled 'Epstein Psych Observation 7-24-30-2019.pdf'. The email and its attachment pertain to the psychological observation and suicide watch logs for inmate Jeffrey Epstein during the period of July 24-30, 2019, shortly before his death. The document includes metadata about the email's creation, delivery, and subsequent legal tagging as responsive and flagged. This document is an email with an attached timeline detailing the events surrounding the suicide of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York on August 10, 2019. It includes a minute-by-minute log of the response and notifications made to various agencies and personnel. This document contains email correspondence and a BOP memorandum related to Jeffrey Epstein's death and subsequent investigations. It includes a detailed suicide timeline from August 9-10, 2019, a forwarded memorandum with feedback on the institution's psychological reconstruction response, and email exchanges regarding legal meetings and conditions at MCC New York. This document contains email chains from 2019 concerning conditions at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) and attorney access issues. The first chain involves attorney Bruce Barket complaining about poor conditions and intimidation faced by his client, Nicholas Tartaglione. The second chain involves a request for Jeffrey Epstein's autopsy and related reports from the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner. The third chain discusses attorney Martin Weinberg's access to Jeffrey Epstein shortly after his arrest. This document contains email correspondence from July to December 2019 regarding legal and administrative issues for two inmates at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It includes concerns about attorney access for Jeffrey Epstein and conditions of confinement for Nick Tartaglione, as well as follow-up on an investigation related to Tartaglione and Epstein. This document is a collection of email correspondence from the Bureau of Prisons system. It includes a forwarded news article about the ousting of the Federal Prisons chief following Jeffrey Epstein's suicide, a newsletter of news articles, and an email chain regarding a request by defense attorney Bruce Barket to view the cell of inmate Nicholas Tartaglione. The emails involve U.S. Attorney's Office staff and prison officials. This document is a collection of email correspondence primarily concerning legal and logistical issues for two federal detainees: Jeffrey Epstein and Nicholas Tartaglione. It includes communications between defense attorneys, prison officials, and prosecutors regarding attorney-client meeting difficulties, conditions of confinement, and case preparation. This document is a forwarded email chain from July 2019 concerning the detention conditions and legal access of inmate Nicholas Tartaglione at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. Defense attorney Bruce Barket details severe issues including leaks, rodents, lack of reading material and discovery, and systemic delays in attorney visits. The email is forwarded to a prison psychologist requesting a mental health evaluation for Tartaglione, who is facing the death penalty. This document is an email chain from July 2019 between defense attorney Bruce Barket and a Supervisory Staff Attorney at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) regarding the detention conditions and legal access difficulties of inmate Nicholas Tartaglione. Barket details systemic problems including long delays for attorney visits, poor cell conditions (leaks, pests, lighting issues), and loss of legal materials, arguing these issues impede Tartaglione's ability to prepare for his death penalty trial. This document contains email correspondence regarding inmate conditions and legal access for Nicholas Tartaglione at MCC New York, followed by a Bureau of Prisons clinical encounter report detailing the medical emergency and resuscitation efforts for Jeffrey Epstein on August 10, 2019, after he was found unresponsive in his cell.

events.title: Attorney swaps client's books
events.description: An attorney (likely Bruce Barket) personally swapped out books for Nicholas Tartaglione at the MCC because guards would not.

events.title: Email complaint about MCC conditions
events.description: Attorney Bruce Barket sends a detailed email to prosecutors complaining about ongoing problems at the MCC faced by his client Nicholas Tartaglione, including intimidation by guards.

events.title: Scheduled call to discuss MCC conditions
events.description: The legal parties (defense and prosecution) coordinate via email to schedule a conference call for the afternoon to discuss the treatment issues raised about Nicholas Tartaglione.

events.title: Tartaglione Book Swap
events.description: An individual (possibly Bruce Barket) swapped out books for inmate Mr. Tartaglione at MCC, as guards had not done so.

events.title: Scheduled Call on MCC Conditions
events.description: Legal professionals schedule a conference call for 2pm or 2:30pm to discuss ongoing problems at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: Epstein Suicide Incident
events.description: The incident involving the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein at MCC. The Office of the Inspector General (OIG) is conducting interviews of staff regarding this event.

events.title: CJAB Meeting
events.description: Upcoming Criminal Justice Act Board (CJAB) meeting where the new MCC Warden is scheduled to address issues including attorney visiting delays and the female unit.

events.title: Staff Attorney Promotion
events.description: The Supervisory Staff Attorney for CLC at MCC is promoted to Deputy Regional Counsel for the Northeast Region in Philadelphia, PA, starting on this date.

events.title: Email discussion on Tartaglione MCC conditions
events.description: Bruce Barket follows up on a government letter to the court, seeking to discuss conditions under which Nick Tartaglione would withdraw his request to be moved from MCC.

events.title: Scheduled client visit before court
events.description: Bruce Barket schedules a visit with his client Nick at MCC at 8:00 AM before a noon court hearing. USMS plans to pick up the client early.

events.title: Request for private investigator visit
events.description: Sarah Sacks requests procedures to get a private investigator appointed under CJA permission for a legal visit with a client at MCC.

events.title: Epstein Plea Deal
events.description: Financier Jeffrey Epstein secured a non-prosecution agreement from federal prosecutors, notably then-U.S. Attorney Alex Acosta, pleading guilty to lesser state charges.

events.title: New Epstein Charges Unsealed
events.description: Federal prosecutors in New York unsealed new sex trafficking charges against Jeffrey Epstein based on new evidence.

events.title: Calls for Acosta's Resignation
events.description: Following the unsealing of new Epstein charges, prominent Democrats and others called for Labor Secretary Alex Acosta to resign over his role in the 2008 plea deal.

events.title: Mar-a-Lago Party with Trump and Epstein
events.description: A 'calendar girl' competition party was held at Mar-a-Lago where Donald Trump and Jeffrey Epstein were reportedly the only male guests.

events.title: Barr's Recusal Decision
events.description: Attorney General William Barr announced he would not recuse from the current Epstein prosecution but would recuse from any review of the 2008 plea deal due to a colleague's past involvement.

events.title: Tech Executives Congressional Testimony
events.description: Apple, Amazon, Facebook, and Google executives will testify before Congress as part of the House's antitrust investigation.

events.title: Assault Incident in Paris
events.description: Egyptian workman Ashraf Eid was allegedly assaulted by Princess Hassa bint Salman's bodyguard in the Saudi king's Paris apartment.

events.title: White House Social Media Summit
events.description: Trump summoned Republican lawmakers, strategists, and social media stars to discuss alleged online censorship.

events.title: D.C. Council Action Against Jack Evans
events.description: The D.C. Council stripped Jack Evans of his committee chairmanship and voted to hire a law firm to investigate him.

events.title: TDY Cost Discussion for MCC NY
events.description: Email correspondence regarding whether Temporary Duty (TDY) costs for staff at MCC New York, incurred while implementing new procedures and policies following an incident, should be covered by a special project fund.

events.title: Epstein Incident at MCC NY
events.description: Referenced incident at the Metropolitan Correctional Center New York, implied to be the Jeffrey Epstein case, leading to the implementation of new local procedures and policies.

events.title: MDC Brooklyn Incident
events.description: A prior incident at the Metropolitan Detention Center Brooklyn where TDY and other costs were covered by a special project fund.

events.title: Scheduled TDY to MCC New York
events.description: Approximately 60 staff from various institutions were scheduled for Temporary Duty (TDY) to MCC New York, with estimated costs of approximately $500,000.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's Arrest and Detention
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested and detained at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York.

events.title: Concerns About Attorney Access
events.description: Email correspondence expresses concern about defendant Jeffrey Epstein not having access to his attorney in advance of his presentment.

events.title: Suicide Watch Log Error
events.description: A staff member (C/O Thomas) used the wrong logbook (VM companion log) instead of the Staff Suicide Watch log for Jeffrey Epstein. The error was discovered and a second, correct log was completed.

events.title: Epstein placed on suicide watch
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was placed on suicide watch at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. Staff logs document 15-minute observations of his behavior.

events.title: Email regarding suicide watch log error
events.description: A BOP email discusses that staff member Thomas used the wrong log book (Inmate Companions Log) instead of the Staff Suicide Watch log for his observations during Epstein's suicide watch. A second, correct log was completed.

events.title: Discussions on TDY funding for MCC New York
events.description: A series of BOP emails discuss the significant costs (approx. $500,000) for Temporary Duty (TDY) staff sent to MCC New York following the Epstein incident. There is initial confusion over whether a special project (87F, 'Epstein Death') can cover these expenses, which is later approved.

events.title: Epstein removed from Psych Observation/Suicide Watch
events.description: An email states inmate Epstein is being taken off Psych Observation and Suicide Watch and needs to be housed with an appropriate cellmate.

events.title: Epstein commits suicide
events.context: Referenced in a later email about inmate Michael Elansky, which states 'the night Epstein committed suicide'.

events.title: Rabbi reports medical emergency for inmate Elansky
events.description: Rabbi Shmuel Spritzer sends an email describing inmate Michael Elansky's severe medical condition (migraines, vomiting, tremors) and alleged neglect, referencing Epstein's suicide.

events.title: Internal email on MCC Chicago staffing
events.description: An email chain discusses staffing levels at MCC Chicago, expressing concern to avoid 'another Epstein episode'.

events.title: Epstein's Last Full Day
events.description: Epstein spends the day in attorney conferences. His cellmate Reyes Efrain departs for court and does not return. In the evening, Epstein is reported in good spirits after a social call.

events.title: Epstein Found Unresponsive and Pronounced Dead
events.description: At 6:33 am, staff find Epstein unresponsive in his SHU cell. CPR is initiated, EMS is called, and he is transported to Beekman Hospital where he is pronounced dead at 7:36 am. Multiple agencies (FBI, OIG, USMS) are notified.

events.title: Notifications and Investigation Launch
events.description: Following Epstein's death, a series of notifications are made to the FBI (8:34 am), AUSA (9:00 am), Judge Berman (10:00 am), next of kin (11:00 am), and the public via press release. The FBI and OIG arrive at the institution to investigate.

events.title: OIG Interview Requests
events.description: The Office of the Inspector General (OIG) requests to interview MCC medical staff regarding the Epstein incident, seeking voluntary interviews.

events.title: Attorney Meeting Arranged
events.description: Attorney Bruce Barket arranges a meeting with his client Nick Tartaglione for 5:00 pm, facilitated by MCC Staff Attorney.

events.title: Complaint About MCC Conditions
events.description: Attorney Bruce Barket emails MCC staff detailing ongoing problems for his client Nick Tartaglione, including lack of books/batteries, intimidating comments from guards, and visiting room staffing issues.

events.title: Book Swap by Attorney
events.description: Bruce Barket personally swapped out books for his client, Mr. Tartaglione, at the MCC because the guards were not doing it.

events.title: Email Complaint about MCC Conditions
events.description: Attorney Bruce Barket sends an email detailing ongoing problems at the MCC, including guards refusing to provide batteries and books, and making intimidating comments to his client.

events.title: Request for PI Visitation Approval
events.description: Attorney Sarah Sacks submits a BOP visitation form and credentials for private investigator Joseph O'Brien to visit inmate Nikolai Niftalijev at the MCC.

events.title: Arrest of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested and detained at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC).

events.title: Attorney Access Denied at MCC
events.description: Epstein's attorney, Martin Weinberg, was denied entry to MCC to meet with his client because he was from out-of-state, raising concerns about Epstein's access to counsel before his presentment.

events.title: Epstein Suicide Investigation
events.description: Mentioned in a November 2019 email, indicating there was ongoing interest in the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death by suicide.

events.title: Google Alert on Bureau of Prisons and Epstein
events.description: A Google Alert email is sent containing news articles, including one about Jeffrey Epstein's suicide attempt at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: Email Correspondence on New Warden and Meeting
events.description: Email exchange between Judge Valerie Caproni and a Bureau of Prisons Supervisory Staff Attorney discussing a new warden, an upcoming CIAB/CJAB meeting, attorney visiting study delays, and the Epstein suicide investigation.

events.title: Google Alert on Bureau of Prisons Updates
events.description: A Google Alert email is sent containing news articles, including one revealing that jail video of Jeffrey Epstein's first suicide attempt was deleted and that the BOP declined to comment.

events.title: Epstein's Arrest
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested and detained at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York.

events.title: Reported Suicide Attempt
events.description: Media reports surfaced (via Radaronline) that Jeffrey Epstein had attempted suicide at MCC. The BOP Public Information Office was contacted for confirmation.

events.title: Day Before Suicide
events.description: Epstein met with attorneys throughout the day. His cellmate, Reyes Efrain, departed for court and did not return.

events.title: Epstein's Suicide and Death
events.description: Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at 6:33 am. CPR was initiated, and he was transported to Beekman Hospital where he was pronounced dead at 7:36 am. A detailed internal timeline documents the response.

events.title: Investigation Launch
events.description: Following Epstein's death, the FBI, OIG (Office of the Inspector General), and other agencies were notified and arrived at MCC to investigate.

events.title: CPAP Machine Inquiry
events.description: Email chain regarding inmate Jeffrey Epstein's need for his CPAP machine, which he claimed to have had at the time of his arrest. Staff confirm with his attorneys that he has one at home and discuss paperwork for him to receive it in prison.

events.title: Medication and Grooming Arrangements
events.description: Emails discuss allegations from Epstein's attorneys that he is not receiving cholesterol or back pain medication. The chief pharmacist confirms an active prescription for Vascepa and notes no Rx for back pain. Separate email discusses a delay for an attorney conference due to Epstein getting a shower, haircut, and medical assessment.

events.title: Extension Cord Memo
events.description: An email is sent with an attachment titled 'EXTENSION CORD MEMO' regarding inmate Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Google Alert on Epstein's Death
events.description: A Google Alert email contains a news headline: 'Jeffrey Epstein Autopsy Report Shows Broken Neck'. It notes Attorney General Barr demanded an investigation.

events.title: CPAP Extension Cord Request
events.description: M.D., Acting Clinical Director, writes a memo requesting an electrical extension cord for inmate Jeffrey Epstein to use his CPAP machine during the evening.

events.title: Epstein's Death
events.description: Epstein found unresponsive in his cell at 6:33 am. CPR initiated, EMS arrives, and he is transported to Beekman Hospital. Official time of death reported at 7:36 am by an ER physician. Multiple agencies notified (FBI, OIG, USMS, AUSA).

events.title: Post-Death Procedures
events.description: Next of kin (brother) notified, press release issued, body released to Medical Examiner, FBI and OIG investigate on-site, and computer hard drives from SHU are removed.

events.title: Warden's Response to Judge
events.description: Supervisory Staff Attorney Greco emails the Warden's response to an inquiry from Judge Richard M. Berman regarding Epstein's death.

events.title: Medical Records Release Process
events.description: A Staff Attorney emails defense counsel Michael outlining the procedure for releasing Epstein's medical/mental health records post-mortem, noting HIPAA rights do not survive death.

events.title: Incident at MCC involving Epstein
events.description: An unspecified incident involving Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, which was subject to an internal investigation and later included in FBI and OIG investigations.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at MCC at approximately 6:33 AM. CPR was initiated, EMS transported him to Beekman Hospital, and he was pronounced dead at 7:36 AM.

events.title: Epstein's last attorney visits
events.description: Epstein was in attorney conferences with several attorneys throughout the day, returning to the SHU at 6:45 PM. He was reported to be in good spirits during a social call at 7:00 PM.

events.title: Barr removes acting prisons director
events.description: Attorney General William Barr ordered the removal of the acting US prisons director following Epstein's death, as reported in a Google Alert news summary.

events.title: Google Alert on Prison News
events.description: A Google Alerts email digest was generated containing various news headlines about prisons worldwide, including one referencing Jeffrey Epstein's death.

events.title: The Daily 202 Newsletter on Trade War
events.description: The Washington Post's newsletter discussed economic uncertainty, Trump's delay of tariffs on Chinese goods, recession indicators, and political news including the Blagojevich commutation consideration.

events.title: Rod Blagojevich Reports to Prison
events.description: Former Illinois Governor Rod Blagojevich reported to federal prison to serve his sentence for corruption.

events.title: Trump Considers Blagojevich Commutation
events.description: President Trump appeared to back away from imminent plans to commute Rod Blagojevich's sentence after Republican lawmakers expressed opposition.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by apparent suicide in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York while awaiting trial on sex trafficking charges.

events.title: DOJ Reassigns MCC Warden
events.description: Following Epstein's death, the Justice Department reassigned the warden of the MCC and placed two staff members on leave due to 'serious irregularities' and failure to keep Epstein secure.

events.title: Guards Falsified Logs
events.description: The two prison staff members guarding Epstein fell asleep, failed to check on him for three hours, and falsely recorded in logs that they had performed required 30-minute checks.

events.title: 4chan Post Precedes Official News
events.description: Details of Epstein's death were posted on 4chan more than 30 minutes before it became public news, prompting an investigation into a potential leak from first responders.

events.title: Trump Promotes Clinton Conspiracy Theory
events.description: President Trump retweeted a message from Terrence K. Williams suggesting Bill Clinton was involved in Epstein's death and later defended the retweet.

events.title: Scrutiny of Prince Andrew
events.description: Following Epstein's death, Prince Andrew faced renewed scrutiny over a 2001 photograph with an alleged Epstein victim and accusations of sexual encounters.

events.title: Hong Kong Airport Protests
events.description: Hong Kong protesters occupied the airport's departure halls for a second day, leading to clashes with police, arrests, and warnings of severe punishment from authorities.

events.title: Russian Missile Test Explosion
events.description: A missile test explosion in Russia caused a radiation spike and the evacuation of the village of Nyonoksa.

events.title: ICE Raids in Mississippi
events.description: ICE raids in Mississippi resulted in the arrest of hundreds of immigrant workers, primarily in the poultry industry. U.S. citizens lined up for the now-vacant jobs.

events.title: Debate Over Migrant Children Shelter in D.C.
events.description: A federal contractor applied to open a temporary shelter for up to 242 unaccompanied migrant children in Washington, D.C., but Mayor Muriel Bowser said she would not accept the plan.

events.title: House Panel Gun-Control Debate
events.description: A House panel with jurisdiction over firearms was expected to return early from recess to vote on new gun-control measures, but Democrats were privately sparring over specifics, including an assault weapons ban.

events.title: New York Times Editor Demoted
events.description: The New York Times demoted its congressional editor, Jonathan Weisman, after he made problematic comments on Twitter that were criticized as racist.

events.title: DOJ Investigation into Epstein's Death
events.description: Attorney General Barr decried 'serious irregularities' at the MCC, reassigned the warden, and placed two staff members on leave following Epstein's death.

events.title: Trump Comments on Epstein Death Conspiracy
events.description: President Trump defended retweeting a conspiracy theory linking the Clintons to Epstein's death, stating it came from a 'respected conservative pundit.'

events.title: Complaint about Tartaglione's SHU Conditions
events.description: Defense attorney Bruce Barket emailed a Supervisory Staff Attorney detailing poor and potentially punitive conditions for his client Nicholas Tartaglione in the MCC SHU.

events.title: Hong Kong Protests Escalate
events.description: Hong Kong protests paralyzed the airport, leading to clashes. China threatened military-style force, and Trump commented ambiguously on the situation.

events.title: Visitation Delay for Tartaglione
events.description: Bruce Barket arrives at MCC at 7:56 AM but is not allowed to see his client Nicholas Tartaglione until after 9:00 AM, resulting in less than 30 minutes of meeting time.

events.title: Previous Incident Involving Epstein
events.description: An incident occurred where it was unclear if Epstein engaged in self-directed violence or was assaulted. An incident report was written presuming self-harm, which the later memo criticizes as evidence of bias.

events.title: BOP Feedback Memorandum Issued
events.description: The BOP Reentry Services Division sends a memo to the Northeast Regional Director providing critical feedback on MCC New York's response to the psychological reconstruction of Epstein's suicide, citing unclear or insufficient corrective actions.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's Suicide at MCC
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York, triggering a major shake-up at the Bureau of Prisons and multiple investigations.

events.title: BOP TDY Staff Deployment to MCC New York
events.description: Approximately 60 BOP staff from various institutions were scheduled for Temporary Duty (TDY) at MCC New York to implement new procedures and policies following Epstein's death, with estimated costs of $500,000.

events.title: Barr Demotes Federal Prison Director
events.description: News report that Attorney General William Barr demoted the Federal Prison Director and tapped an old colleague amid the shake-up following Epstein's suicide.

events.title: Out of Office Notification
events.description: An individual (name redacted) states they will be out of the office from August 12-16, 2019, providing contact information for FCI Estill and MCC New York.

events.title: Attorney Access Issue for Epstein
events.description: Email chain discusses concerns about Jeffrey Epstein not having access to his attorney (Marlin Weinberg) after his arrest and detention at MCC New York.

events.title: BOP Budget Discussions for Epstein Aftermath
events.description: Internal BOP emails discuss TDY (temporary duty) costs for staff at MCC New York related to the 'Epstein Death', estimating costs of approximately $500,000 and referencing a special project code (87F).

events.title: Site Visit Request for Tartaglione
events.description: Attorney Bruce Barket requests to view cells and common areas where his client, Mr. Tartaglione, has been held at MCC New York for penalty phase preparation.

events.title: Tartaglione Suicide Attempt
events.description: Nicholas Tartaglione attempted suicide while in custody at MCC. The emails discuss obtaining video of the attempt and the rope used.

events.title: Request to View Tartaglione's Cell
events.description: Defense attorney Bruce Barket requests to view the cells and common areas where Tartaglione has been held in preparation for a potential penalty phase.

events.title: Epstein Investigation Check
events.description: Email confirms there is no investigation into Nicholas Tartaglione related to Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Attorney Visit and Condition Report
events.description: Bruce Barket visits Nicholas Tartaglione in SHU. Tartaglione reports ongoing poor conditions: water leak, dead rodent in bed, lack of books and discovery, and threats of severe punishment from a guard.

events.title: Delayed Legal Visit
events.description: Bruce Barket arrives for a Sunday visit but experiences significant delays, not gaining access to his client until over an hour after arrival, cutting the visit short.

events.title: Defense Team Complaints and Prosecution Response
events.description: Bruce Barket sends a detailed email listing systemic problems with visiting Tartaglione. The prosecution and prison staff respond, outlining steps being taken to address some complaints regarding books, legal work, and recreation.

events.title: Order in Epstein Case Forwarded
events.description: An email is forwarded containing a court order related to the case 'USA v. Jeffrey Epstein 19 cr 490'. The forwarder notes they and legal will likely attend.

events.title: Court Hearing on Dismissal of Epstein Indictment
events.description: Judge Berman schedules a hearing to address the government's proposed dismissal of the indictment against Jeffrey Epstein following his death, allowing counsel for the government, the deceased defendant, and victims to be heard.

events.title: Epstein Arrest and Attorney Access Issue
events.description: Email chain discusses concerns about Jeffrey Epstein, arrested the previous night and detained at MCC, not having access to his attorney (Martin Weinberg) before his presentment.

events.title: Epstein Removed from Psych Observation
events.description: Email indicates inmate Jeffrey Epstein is being taken off Psych Observation and needs to be housed with an appropriate cellmate.

events.title: Complaints about Tartaglione's Jail Conditions
events.description: Email from Bruce Barket details numerous complaints about Nicholas Tartaglione's conditions in SHU at MCC, including leaks, pests, lack of discovery, and restricted privileges.

events.title: Delayed Attorney Visit
events.description: Bruce Barket and Aida Leisenring arrived at MCC at 7:55 AM but Tartaglione was not brought to the attorney conference room until almost 9:30 AM, resulting in a very short meeting.

events.title: SHU Lieutenant Meeting with Tartaglione
events.description: The SHU Lieutenant met with Tartaglione to discuss his personal property, including limiting him to 5 books in his cell and mailing 151 others home, as well as recreation and law library procedures.

events.title: Sunday Visit Delays
events.description: Bruce Barket arrived for a Sunday visit at 7:56 AM but experienced significant delays, not seeing Tartaglione until after 9:00 AM, cutting the visit short due to a 10:00 AM count.

events.title: Tartaglione Finds Dead Rodent
events.description: Tartaglione reported finding a dead rodent in his bed, which he apparently smothered accidentally while sleeping, highlighting the unsanitary cell conditions.

events.title: Psychological Evaluation Request
events.description: The Supervisory Staff Attorney requests that Tartaglione be seen for a psychological evaluation due to facing the death penalty and being in SHU under disciplinary charges.

events.title: Email regarding Epstein Suicide Watch
events.description: Carla Melendez sends an email with the subject 'Re: Fwd: Inmate Epstein #76318-054 (Suicide Watch)', indicating internal BOP communication about Epstein's status.

events.title: AG Barr's visit to FCI Edgefield
events.description: News articles are forwarded about Attorney General William Barr's visit to FCI Edgefield prison. One article notes Barr recused himself from the Epstein case.

events.title: Distribution of Updated Epstein Timeline
events.description: An email is sent with the subject 'Updated Timeline-Epstein, Jeffrey Edward, Reg. No. 73618-054_1', attaching a document, indicating internal BOP record-keeping about Epstein.

events.title: Google Alert on Bureau of Prisons
events.description: A Google Alert email summarizes news about the BOP, including a report that moving Epstein's body after his suicide violated federal prison guidelines.

events.title: Previous Incident in Cell
events.description: A prior incident involving Epstein where it was unclear if he engaged in 'self-directed violence' or was assaulted. An incident report was written presuming self-harm, which a later review cited as evidence of bias.

events.title: Criminal Case Officially Closed
events.description: Judge Berman officially closed the sex trafficking criminal case against Jeffrey Epstein following his death.

events.title: BOP Memo on Psychological Reconstruction
events.description: The Assistant Director of the Reentry Services Division sent a memo to the Regional Director criticizing the institution's response to the psychological reconstruction of Epstein's suicide, citing unclear corrective actions and institutional failures.

events.title: Email Chain Forwarded re: Tartaglione Conditions
events.description: A supervisory staff attorney at MCC forwards an email chain from defense attorney Bruce Barket complaining about inmate Nicholas Tartaglione's conditions and access issues, tasking various MCC departments to investigate.

events.title: Bruce Barket's Visit to MCC
events.description: Bruce Barket visits client Nicholas Tartaglione at MCC, experiences significant delays, and later writes an email detailing the systemic problems with attorney access and poor conditions in the SHU.

events.title: Prosecutor Updates on Discovery and Transfer
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney communicates with Bruce Barket, explaining a delay in delivering a discovery hard drive and informing him that the Marshals have refused to transfer Tartaglione to Nassau County.

events.title: Email Chain on Tartaglione Conditions
events.description: A supervisory staff attorney at MCC forwards defense attorney Bruce Barket's complaints about inmate Nicholas Tartaglione's conditions to various prison departments for investigation.

events.title: Barket's Visit to Tartaglione
events.description: Bruce Barket visits client Nicholas Tartaglione at MCC and reports ongoing poor conditions, including a leaking cell, denied privileges, and lack of updated discovery.

events.title: Prosecutor Declines Inmate Transfer
events.description: Assistant U.S. Attorney Jason informs Bruce Barket that the U.S. Marshals have refused a request to transfer Nicholas Tartaglione to Nassau County Jail.

events.title: Psychological Observation of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: A separate email attachment references a psychological observation report for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, utilizing an "I/M companion" (inmate companion).

events.title: Start of Epstein's Psychological Observation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is placed on psychological observation and/or suicide watch at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York.

events.title: End of Documented Observation Period
events.description: The documented period of psychological observation for Jeffrey Epstein ends.

events.title: Email Forwarding Observation Logs
events.description: An Associate Warden sends an email with the subject 'Psych Observation 7/24-30/19 (I/M companion utilized) re: Epstein, Jeffrey Edward, Reg. No. 73618-054', attaching the observation logs.

events.title: Document Tagged as Responsive and Flagged
events.description: The email record is tagged as 'Responsive' and 'Flagged' in a legal or review process, likely related to the investigation into Epstein's death.

events.title: Epstein Found Unresponsive
events.description: At 6:33 am, a body alarm is activated. Staff find Epstein unresponsive in his cell. CPR is initiated, EMS is called, and he is transported to Beekman Hospital where he is pronounced dead at 7:36 am.

events.title: Notifications and Investigations Begin
events.description: Following the incident, a series of notifications are made to the Warden, USMS, FBI, AUSA, Judge Berman, next of kin, and OIG. The FBI and OIG arrive at the MCC to investigate.

events.title: Epstein's last full day
events.description: Epstein meets with attorneys throughout the day. His cellmate Reyes departs for court and does not return. Epstein is reported in good spirits during a social call at 7:00 pm.

events.title: Epstein found unresponsive and pronounced dead
events.description: At 6:33 am, staff find Epstein unresponsive in his SHU cell. CPR is initiated, EMS transports him to Beekman Hospital, and he is pronounced dead at 7:36 am. Multiple agencies (FBI, OIG, AUSA, Judge Berman) are notified.

events.title: BOP Reentry Services Division feedback memorandum
events.description: The BOP Reentry Services Division sends a memorandum to the Northeast Regional Director providing feedback on MCC New York's response to the psychological reconstruction of Epstein's suicide, citing unclear or insufficient corrective actions.

events.title: Previous incident involving Epstein
events.description: Referenced in the feedback as an incident where an incident report was written for Epstein prior to determining if it was self-directed violence or an assault. SIS could not determine the nature of the incident.

events.title: Tartaglione book swap
events.description: An individual (possibly a guard) swapped out books for inmate Nicholas Tartaglione at MCC.

events.title: Attorney complaint about MCC conditions
events.description: Attorney Bruce Barket emails prosecutors detailing ongoing problems at MCC, including denial of property and intimidating comments by guards towards his client.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein arrested
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested and detained at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC).

events.title: Attorney access issue for Epstein
events.description: Email chain discusses ensuring out-of-state attorney Martin Weinberg has access to meet with defendant Jeffrey Epstein at MCC.

events.title: Autopsy request letter sent
events.description: A certified letter requesting Jeffrey Epstein's autopsy report and related documents was sent to the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner.

events.title: Follow-up on autopsy request
events.description: A Health Services Administrator at MCC follows up with the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner to request Epstein's autopsy report, discharge summary, toxicology report, and death certificate.

events.title: Epstein Attorney Access Issue
events.description: Martin Weinberg, Epstein's attorney, was denied access to meet with Epstein at MCC prior to his presentment because he was from out-of-state.

events.title: Tartaglione Placed in SHU
events.description: Nick Tartaglione was placed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at MCC based on an allegation of possessing a cell phone.

events.title: Follow-up on Tartaglione/Epstein Investigation
events.description: Prosecutors confirm no investigation into Tartaglione regarding Epstein, and follow up on obtaining video and evidence from Tartaglione's July 2019 suicide attempt.

events.title: Federal Prisons Chief Ousted
events.description: The Bureau of Prisons chief was ousted following the jailhouse suicide of Jeffrey Epstein, which highlighted mismanagement and staffing issues.

events.title: Epstein Suicide
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide in federal custody, leading to scrutiny of the Bureau of Prisons.

events.title: ACLU Files Lawsuit for Inmate Medication
events.description: The ACLU sues a federal prison in Kansas to force it to provide an inmate with buprenorphine, an opioid addiction medication.

events.title: Request to View Tartaglione Cell
events.description: Defense attorney Bruce Barket requests to view the cells and common areas where his client, Nicholas Tartaglione, has been held in preparation for a potential penalty phase.

events.title: Epstein Victims Come Forward in Paris
events.description: Three individuals who declare they were victims of Jeffrey Epstein come forward in France and are questioned by prosecutors.

events.title: Difficulty with Attorney Access for Epstein
events.description: Prison officials verify attorney Martin Weinberg's standing and permit him to visit Jeffrey Epstein after concerns were raised about Epstein not having access to his attorney before presentment.

events.title: Ongoing Visitation and Condition Issues for Tartaglione
events.description: A series of emails detail persistent problems for defense attorney Bruce Barket and his team in visiting client Nicholas Tartaglione at MCC, including long delays, broken equipment, and poor conditions in the SHU.

events.title: Complaints about Tartaglione's MCC Conditions
events.description: Defense attorney Bruce Barket sends detailed emails documenting poor conditions for client Nicholas Tartaglione in SHU at MCC New York, including leaks, rodents, lack of books/discovery, and systemic delays in attorney visits.

events.title: Request for Psychological Evaluation
events.description: A supervisory staff attorney requests the chief psychologist to have Tartaglione seen for a mental health evaluation, citing he is facing the death penalty and is in SHU.

events.title: Attorney Visit Delays at MCC
events.description: Bruce Barket describes arriving at MCC at 7:56 AM but not being able to see his client until after 9:00 AM due to staffing issues, cutting the visit short.

events.title: Attorney Visit Delay
events.description: Bruce Barket arrives at MCC at 7:56 AM but experiences significant delays, not seeing client Tartaglione until after 9:00 AM, resulting in less than 30 minutes of consultation.

events.title: Discovery Delivery Issue
events.description: Communication about a hard drive containing discovery for Tartaglione being misrouted within the USAO, causing a delay in him receiving it.

events.title: Complaints About Cell Conditions
events.description: Barket reports after a visit that Tartaglione's cell has constant water leaks, pest issues (a rodent), malfunctioning lights, and that he lacks books and discovery.

events.title: Internal MCC Tasking
events.description: The Supervisory Staff Attorney forwards Barket's complaints to various MCC departments (Facilities, Safety, SIS, SHU) for investigation into cell leaks, pests, incident reports, and property issues.

events.title: Delayed Attorney Visit with Tartaglione
events.description: Bruce Barket and Aida visited Nicholas Tartaglione but experienced a significant delay, waiting from 7:55 AM until almost 9:30 AM for him to be brought to the conference room, resulting in only a 20-30 minute meeting.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein Found Unresponsive
events.description: Emergency response to Jeffrey Epstein's cell at 06:35 where he was found unresponsive on the floor, cold, with bruising around the neck, fixed pupils, and no pulse. CPR was initiated by correctional officers.

events.title: Epstein Resuscitation and Transport
events.description: Extended resuscitation efforts on Epstein including CPR, AED (no shock advised), intubation by paramedics, administration of epinephrine and sodium bicarbonate, and transport to a local ER with CPR in progress.

keyFacts: Defense attorney Bruce Barket reported that guards at the MCC were intimidating his client Nicholas Tartaglione with comments like 'You're threatening our lives' and 'Give the big mouth his try.'
Tartaglione had not had his books swapped since August 15th, when his attorney had to do it himself, and guards refused to provide batteries for his radio.
Attorney Barket experienced significant delays for legal visits due to inadequate staffing in the MCC lobby, waiting nearly 50 minutes on one occasion.
The email chain shows coordination between defense and prosecution (including AUSA Aida Leisenring) to schedule a call to address these detention condition issues.
The document is part of a larger file that begins with a Google Alerts email digest about 'ethics,' showing how this legal correspondence was archived and tagged as responsive and flagged in 2020.
Attorney Bruce Barket details poor conditions for his client Mr. Tartaglione at MCC, including guards refusing to provide books and batteries and making intimidating comments.
The Office of the Inspector General (OIG) is actively investigating the incident involving Jeffrey Epstein's death and seeks to interview MCC staff, including medical personnel.
A BOP Supervisory Staff Attorney informs Judge Caproni that there is no new information on the Epstein suicide investigation as it is still under review by the FBI, OIG, and USAO.
Email correspondence shows coordination among legal professionals to schedule a call addressing systemic problems at the MCC facility.
The document reveals internal BOP communication about operational challenges, including union issues affecting an attorney waiting times study and staffing shortages.
